summary: The Public Health Improvement Act aims to reform the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Key provisions include limiting the terms of the CDC and NIH directors to a maximum of 12 years, modifying the CDC's strategic plan, altering the composition of the CDC advisory committee, narrowing the scope of HHS regulations regarding communicable diseases, requiring Congressional approval for public health emergencies, and transferring several CDC offices to the National Institutes of Health (NIH). The Act also mandates the Secretary of Health and Human Services to issue new or revised regulations to implement the changes and includes a preemption clause.
